title: 109_s1289
content: The Act may be cited as the "Uterine Fibroid Research and Education Act of 2005". It includes findings related to uterine fibroids. Congress finds that uterine fibroids are a common health issue affecting women of reproductive age, with a higher prevalence among minority women. Studies show that between 20-30% of women have clinically recognized fibroids, and ultrasound screenings indicate even higher prevalence rates. Symptomatic uterine fibroids can cause heavy bleeding, pain, and reproductive problems, including infertility. The presence of uterine fibroids is the most common reason for hysterectomies, accounting for approximately one-third of hysterectomies annually. Over five billion dollars are spent annually on hysterectomies for fibroids. The lack of high-quality evidence supporting the effectiveness of most interventions for symptomatic fibroids is highlighted. Current research does not provide adequate information on the prevalence and incidents of fibroids in minority women, the costs associated with treatment, and prevention methods for these women. Research with respect to uterine fibroids. The Director of the National Institutes of Health will expand and coordinate research programs on uterine fibroids through various institutes and offices. The Office of Research on Women's Health will oversee coordination among different NIH entities. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for $30,000,000 annually from 2006 to 2010 is provided for carrying out research programs on uterine fibroids. SEC. 4. EDUCATION AND DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION REGARDING UTERINE FIBROIDS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop and share information on uterine fibroids, including prevalence among women, higher risk for minority women, and treatment options. Information may be disseminated through various organizations and agencies. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out the development and dissemination of information on uterine fibroids. Sums may be appropriated for fiscal years 2006 through 2010. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide information to healthcare providers about uterine fibroids, including the elevated risk for minority women and treatment options. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose for fiscal years 2006 through 2010. The term "minority women" in this Act refers to women who are members of a racial and ethnic minority group, as defined in the Public Health Service Act.
